history.content:
Nope, not really. (I didn't read it)

The P&H book is quite helpful for a lot of the MIPS, CPU, and cache units, and a little bit for VM.

---

Another answer here. I never used it, got an A. Paid close attention to lectures, took detailed notes on the lectures, used those to study.

Nope, not really. (I didn't read it)


The P&H book is quite helpful for a lot of the MIPS, CPU, and cache units, and a little bit for VM.

children.subject: The C book is somewhat useful but you don't necessarily need either in my opinion

I found the P&H book good, but it had several errors that should have been caught by proofreaders, like text layout problems, a bug in the C-to-MIPS sorting implementation that was silently fixed in the following pages, etc. I'd recommend reading it nonetheless for a better understanding of the material. K&R C is a classic that you should read anyways regardless of the class requirement.

Well I had a lot of help from the curve. Professors decided to curve it to a B+, not a B-. So I think 1 standard deviation above was an A. 

As for how I studied:

I put a lot of work into it; it was my main focus by far. My other grades slipped a little because of this course.

In the end I did:

half a standard deviation above on MT1

Average on MT 2

100% on all the projects/labs/hw

1 1/3 standard deviation above on the final

I took detailed notes on every lecture, did all the discussions, did all the labs. After MT2 it was clear that the professors were actively avoiding old test questions, so I did not do any practice finals for the final. Instead, I just reviewed material and made sure I understood every little concept. I believe that was the reason why I scored what I did on the final and why I got an A, just lucky that I took the right approach in studying. Most of my friends still focused on past final exams. 

I hope that helps a little for you when you take it!

one strategy i found helpful for 61c was to just pay attention and listen to the professors during lectures and then spend roughly an hour or so after each lecture going over the slides again and then taking notes. this worked for me because i could actually focus my attention on what the professors were saying instead of trying to think about what to write down in my notes and listen to the lecture at the same time. in addition this helped me review stuff from the lecture that i spaced out on and made reviewing for midterms really easy because i could just go back and skim over my notes and remember what we covered.
Thanks! They are very good strategies. Also, if you don't mind me asking, do you have strategies for doing labs and projects since projects are pretty difficult I heard?

one strategy i found helpful for 61c was to just pay attention and listen to the professors during lectures and then spend roughly an hour or so after each lecture going over the slides again and then taking notes. this worked for me because i could actually focus my attention on what the professors were saying instead of trying to think about what to write down in my notes and listen to the lecture at the same time. in addition this helped me review stuff from the lecture that i spaced out on and made reviewing for midterms really easy because i could just go back and skim over my notes and remember what we covered.

Original anon here. Yeah this pretty much, except I was lazy and didn't do the original "listening to the professors once". 

The thing about labs and projects is, unlike midterms where you can study a ton and completely bomb it, I find putting in the time for labs/projects correlates linearly with how well you do.

For example, most people bombed Project 1 because they disregarded the spec instructions to debug their C code. Ended up their code didn't compile -> got a zero. A lot of students put in the extra few hours and basically got a free grade bucket out of it by at least making sure the code ran. Project 2-1 had similar testing requirements. 

Many people took a lower score for Project 3-2 because it was stacked during midterm 2. It was just unfortunate and I think no 61c student had a good week's rest that week. Personally, I prioritized Project 3-2 and took the hit on my midterm, scoring average (but getting REALLY lucky in scoring average, I truly believe I deserved a lower score on that exam). Projects 4 and 5 were relatively linear and if you spent the time working on it and started early, you were fine. But some students had burned out by then and slacked off. 

Major tip with projects is just to work with people. Live at all the office hours, don't go for the TA, go for the students. I found that the majority of people that went to office hours were people who generally finished projects earlier. As such I could ask them for tips and watch for potential pitfalls ahead. 

Make no mistake, this class is a grind. Looking back the material was fun and challenging, but it definitely did not feel that way mid-slog.
For the student's answer.. How did you study for CS 61C to get A? I took it earlier this semester but it went by too fast that I have to drop it..
